programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Dive in Tokyo
programme.sub-title: Hakone - From Barrier Station to Relaxing Retreat
programme.desc: We visit Hakone in Kanagawa Prefecture. Once the site of a security checkpoint for traffic in and out of old Tokyo, it evolved into a hot spring resort, now with an increasingly diverse community.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: KABUKI KOOL
programme.desc: Every hero needs a good villain, and kabuki has everything from ambitious schemers to vile seducers and even the odd comic villain. Actor Kataoka Ainosuke explores the roles' appeal.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Writing to Make a Dent in the World: Otani Akira / Author
programme.desc: In 2025, Otani Akira's book "The Night of Baba Yaga" won the UK's prestigious Dagger prize for crime fiction in translation - a first for a Japanese author. She talks about the inspiration behind her work.

programme.title: Japan's Top Inventions
programme.desc: Discover the stories behind renowned Japanese products alongside our reporter. This time: super-absorbent towels.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Tradition and Innovation in Sake Brewing
programme.desc: 92-year-old sake brewer Noguchi Naohiko has made significant contributions to the sake industry over his seven-decade career. He talks about carrying on old traditions while innovating new ones.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: We look at the penultimate 14th day of sumo tournaments, and dive into historical moments that prove this day can be as or more exciting than the final one, like an emotional brotherly title win!

programme.title: The Beauty of Japanese Swords
programme.desc: Japanese swords, admired since ancient times for their beauty, are amazing works of art. This time, a blade wielded by Miyamoto Musashi, the world's most famous swordsman: Musashi Masamune.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: Reproduction of Nihonbashi: Morning Scene by Utagawa Hiroshige
programme.desc: Mornings begin early for fishmongers and vegetable peddlers at Nihonbashi Bridge, and here is a reason. They are not going to bow to the lord's procession. The bustling scene from everyday Edo life.

programme.title: BIZ STREAM
programme.desc: [On-Site Report: Shoring Up Short-Handed Kitchens] This episode features new services and cooking equipment designed to help restaurants in Japan overcome a deepening labor shortage.

programme.title: FRONTRUNNERS
programme.desc: Watanabe Hiroki is co-founder of an NGO in Bangladesh. It gives long-term support to underprivileged children on the street, proving that they can make a positive contribution to society.

programme.title: Japan Railway Journal
programme.sub-title: On Track for a Carbon-Free Future

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: SILK Road: Threads of History from Gunma to Yokohama
programme.desc: In 1859, when Japan reopened its doors after more than two centuries of isolation, goods flowed in and out of newly expanded ports. At the time, raw silk became the country's largest export, as the silk industries in France and Italy had been hit by an epidemic of silkworm disease. At one point, Japan was the world's biggest exporter. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Sheila Cliffe from the UK follows the Silk Road from northern Kanto, once a major production area, to Yokohama, where the silk took off to the world.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: DEEPER LOOK
programme.sub-title: Charting the Future of the Olympics: David Wallechinsky / Co-Founder, International Society of Olympic Historians
programme.desc: What's next for the Olympic Games under its first female president? Historian David Wallechinsky joins to discuss the future of the IOC, costs, corruption, inclusion, and Asia's role.

programme.title: Dig More Japan
programme.desc: "Our theme this time is ""Unknown Japan."" We dig a little deeper and explore some of Japan's hidden charms. programme.title: Dining with the Chef Mini
programme.desc: Dining with the Chef Mini introduces traditional techniques and resourceful recipes in just 5 minutes! Chefs Saito and Rika present their unique approaches to cooking delicious Japanese food. In this episode, we'll be making Beef-wrapped Onigiri: pan-fried rice balls wrapped in thinly sliced beef. Join us and learn how to make Beef-wrapped Onigiri at home!

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: A Home That Transcends Language and Identity
programme.desc: Afuso Michie is a Japanese-Brazilian woman who runs a center in Kanagawa Prefecture that offers Japanese language classes and other services which help foreign residents find their footing.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: This time, a technique involving clamping the opponent's shoulder then pulling them down. We take a close look and examine why the under shoulder swing down is becoming more popular!

programme.title: The Beauty of Japanese Swords: Famous Masterpieces

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: Plum Estate, Kameido by Utagawa Hiroshige
programme.desc: With its splendid branches and white plum blossoms, this famous painting is known for captivating Van Gogh. Discover why people were able to tell this was a specific tree at Kameido Umeyashiki.

programme.title: Japan in Focus
programme.sub-title: Ama Divers Restoring the Earthquake-Hit Seabed
programme.desc: In 2024, natural disasters devastated the fishing grounds of the ama (free divers) in Wajima, Noto. We follow their efforts to survey the seabed and revive their tradition.

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: A Mobile "Warabi Mochi" Cart in Fukuoka
programme.desc: A mobile food cart selling a traditional Japanese sweet has been plying the streets of Fukuoka for over 75 years. For three days, we talked to customers fond of a snack unchanged over the decades.

programme.sub-title: Versatile Oil: Smoothing the Way in Everyday Life
programme.desc: Kyoto dominated the oil market 1,000 years ago. Various oils fueled votive lamps, flavored food, preserved wood, and were used in pomade and cosmetics. Oil still plays a key role in the culture today.

programme.title: Outside in Lost in Academia
programme.desc: Norwegian sociolinguist Goran Vaage investigates Japanese laughter, or warai. He analyzes how comedy is ingrained into communication in everyday life and plays a vital role in social connection.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Training Dogs to Save Lives Around the World
programme.desc: Murase Hidehiro trains search-and-rescue dogs to save lives in disaster areas around the world. He talks about the importance of having dogs that are specifically able to respond to disasters in Asia.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: This is a move that can be used either for defense or offense. We take a deep dive into how it works and how it's been employed throughout sumo history to trip up even fearsome opponents!

programme.title: The Beauty of Japanese Swords: Famous Masterpieces
programme.desc: This time, a famous swordsmith's blade that was cherished by the shoguns who ruled Edo-period Japan.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: The Man with the Piercing Gaze
programme.desc: A man strikes a pose in an iconic woodblock print by the artist Sharaku. Who is the mysterious figure ... and what is he doing? And why did the artist want to commemorate the moment? *"The Actor Otani Oniji III as Edobei" (1794) by Toshusai Sharaku

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.sub-title: Chasing a Dream With a Horse
programme.desc: Nishino Masatoshi didn't know what he wanted to do with his life until he learned about horse logging. Now, he's chasing his dream in the forests of Hokkaido with the help of his trusty sidekick, Kap.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.sub-title: Hot Days and Cool Nights Make Tasty Veggies
programme.desc: Hello, it's me, Tama! What do I do on hot summer days? I hide in the shade! This morning, Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are shopping for summer veggies for today's feast. I hope they buy some for me, too!

programme.title: Japanology Plus
programme.desc: *First broadcast on November 6, 2025 Interest in sleep has been growing in Japan. From futuristic high-tech beds to advanced sleepwear, many new products are designed to improve sleep quality. We look at Japan's latest sleep trends.

programme.title: Train Cruise
programme.sub-title: Rice and Sake from Niigata to Yamagata
programme.desc: We journey the JR Hakushin and Uetsu Main Lines of Niigata and Yamagata Prefectures in search of traditional food culture in one of Japan's major rice-producing regions. At Niigata Station we sample sake from the dizzying array on offer. We visit an old brewery that has converted one building into a tourist attraction. One sightseeing trainso popular it's always fully bookedoffers spectacular views of the Sea of Japan. Along the way we try exquisite salmon dishes and other culinary delights.

programme.desc: *First broadcast on November 8, 2025 Japan now has roughly 8.5 million vacant homes. We look at various initiatives that aim to address this issue, including renovating homes as investments or using them to revitalize local communities.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.sub-title: YOKAI: Exploring Hidden Japanese Folklore KITSUNE
programme.desc: The fox, or KITSUNE also holds an identity as a supernatural creature commonly depicted at shrines, known for its ability to masquerade as humans to deceive them, or to provide divine messages.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode focuses on the many words born from the ancient board game, Go, that are now a part of everyday speech.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Ethical Every Day
programme.sub-title: New Farming for a Changing Climate
programme.desc: Climate change continues, and heat is affecting crops. Some Japanese farmers are adjusting to compensate, like a citrus farmer growing subtropical fruits and a farm that generates solar power.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: In September 2018, the Hokkaido Eastern Iburi Earthquake knocked out power of the entire region, affecting up to 2.95 million households. The tremor caused several power plants to shut down, disrupting the electrical frequency. This led to a chain reaction of other power plants to shut down. People's lives were greatly affected, as medical equipment failed and logistics systems were disrupted. What can we do to prevent such large-scale power outages? Find out what research institutes and local communities are doing to take steps against massive blackouts.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Aichi Prefecture / Kataoka Mami (Curator) Tokoname, a pottery town with over 900 years of history, creates products appropriate for the times. Kataoka finds the beauty that's present in functional objects.

programme.title: Train Cruise
programme.sub-title: Rice and Sake from Niigata to Yamagata
programme.desc: We journey the JR Hakushin and Uetsu Main Lines of Niigata and Yamagata Prefectures in search of traditional food culture in one of Japan's major rice-producing regions. At Niigata Station we sample sake from the dizzying array on offer. We visit an old brewery that has converted one building into a tourist attraction. One sightseeing trainso popular it's always fully bookedoffers spectacular views of the Sea of Japan. Along the way we try exquisite salmon dishes and other culinary delights.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: *First broadcast on November 8, 2025 Japan now has roughly 8.5 million vacant homes. We look at various initiatives that aim to address this issue, including renovating homes as investments or using them to revitalize local communities.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.sub-title: YOKAI: Exploring Hidden Japanese Folklore KITSUNE
programme.desc: The fox, or KITSUNE also holds an identity as a supernatural creature commonly depicted at shrines, known for its ability to masquerade as humans to deceive them, or to provide divine messages.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode focuses on the many words born from the ancient board game, Go, that are now a part of everyday speech.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Ethical Every Day
programme.sub-title: New Farming for a Changing Climate
programme.desc: Climate change continues, and heat is affecting crops. Some Japanese farmers are adjusting to compensate, like a citrus farmer growing subtropical fruits and a farm that generates solar power.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: In September 2018, the Hokkaido Eastern Iburi Earthquake knocked out power of the entire region, affecting up to 2.95 million households. The tremor caused several power plants to shut down, disrupting the electrical frequency. This led to a chain reaction of other power plants to shut down. People's lives were greatly affected, as medical equipment failed and logistics systems were disrupted. What can we do to prevent such large-scale power outages? Find out what research institutes and local communities are doing to take steps against massive blackouts.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Aichi Prefecture / Kataoka Mami (Curator) Tokoname, a pottery town with over 900 years of history, creates products appropriate for the times. Kataoka finds the beauty that's present in functional objects.

programme.title: Documentary 360
programme.desc: NHK WORLD-JAPAN's flagship documentary series offers must-see episodes on politics, the economy, social trends, science and the environment in Japan and beyond.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: EXPO 2025 Special Edition: Do the Oceans Hold the Key?
programme.desc: The World Expo 2025 is underway in Osaka, Japan. Bobby Judo and Professor Oki Taikan, a hydrologist visit pavilions focusing on climate change to find out how the ocean can help us combat this urgent global issue.

programme.title: BIZ STREAM
programme.sub-title: Giving a Spark to the Power Grid
programme.desc: [On-Site Report: Giving a Spark to the Power Grid] This episode features strategies to maintain Japan's power grid. One company is trying to attract climbers, and another has turned checking on power poles into a mobile game for local residents.

programme.title: Let's Enjoy MATH with Barky the Dog
programme.desc: Numbler erases a part of a cake delivery memo, resulting in the delivery of four cakes instead of one. Barky solves the mystery by demonstrating the difference between ordinal numbers and cardinal numbers.

programme.title: TAKE TECH
programme.desc: Hand mixers are used in home cooking, but how do the beaters spin so fast? Take a look inside at the different parts and see how they operate.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: The history of Melaka, a city in Malaysia, dates back to the 15th century Melaka Sultanate, when it became a thriving maritime trade hub. During this period, Islam spread rapidly due to the influence of Arab trading partners. In the 16th century, the Portuguese sought control of Melaka to dominate its strategic trade routes. The city later came under Dutch rule in the 17th century, followed by British control in the 19th century. Despite these shifts in colonial rulers, Melaka continued to prosper as a significant port town.

programme.title: National Parks of Japan:Akan-Mashu
programme.desc: Akan-Mashu National Park is home to Lake Akan, Lake Kussharo, and Lake Mashu. It provides unique winter sights and the opportunity to experience the indigenous Ainu culture.

programme.title: RAMEN JAPAN
programme.desc: Two local takes on ramen that kept Hiroshima fed during postwar reconstruction; flavors passed down for generations.

programme.title: Core Kyoto mini
programme.sub-title: Kyoto Walls: Gracefulness molded from earth
programme.desc: The ancient capital's dignified air is in part generated by earthen walls. Discover the aesthetic sensibilities and expertise of a traditional plasterer as he pursues beauty in earthen walls.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #41 Words of support for a coworker
programme.desc: Today: words of support for a coworker. Nguyen Thi Thuy Trang, from Vietnam, works at a company that makes paper products. She began studying Japanese out of a love for Japanese manga, and she came to Japan two years ago as a technical intern. At her job, she works in quality inspection. She needs a high level of focus to check for any imperfections. She'd like to forge a closer bond with her coworkers, who often push themselves to work hard even when they aren't feeling their best. In a roleplay challenge, she must reach out to a coworker who has back pain to offer words of support.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Making use of his vast experience, dyer Izawa Tsuyoshi has added a touch of color to all kinds of things. And two years ago, he began a new undertaking; dyeing old and worn-out clothes black. This has several benefits. Black hides damage and stains and makes old look new. Izawa worked to develop a black dye that would work on fabric of any color. Bringing clothes destined for the trash back in black has brought in so much business that there's currently a three-month waiting list for the service.
